 28 | # Product Profiles: Noah Sclar, Sr. Product Manager at CUES
 29 | 
 30 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67856cee0fdddf4950644a09_Customer_spotlight_-_CUES_-_Noah_Sclar__1200x630_%2525252528Blog%2525252529.webp)
 31 | 
 32 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cb26b36cc62374679f071f_Jon%20Gitlin%20-%20Merge.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/64dd538684e09763589291b7_64c13599abc4a993825ecd2d_Jon%2520Gitlin%2520headshot.webp)
 33 | 
 34 | Jon Gitlin
 35 | 
 36 | Senior Content Marketing Manager
 37 | 
 38 | @Merge
 39 | 
 40 | Welcome to our new content series, “Product Profiles”.
 41 | 
 42 | Every few weeks, we’ll interview a product leader to learn how their organization runs product management, from planning their product roadmap to managing their sprints to collaborating with other teams.
 43 | 
 44 | To kick things off, we chatted with [Noah Sclar](https://www.linkedin.com/in/noah-sclar-333582159/), a Senior Product Development Manager at [CUES](https://www.getcues.com/), which offers a fully-integrated suite of recognition products.
 45 | 
 46 | Noah talked to us about his day-to-day work, how he’s leveled-up as a PM, why they run sprints on a two-week cadence, how they approach product integrations, and more.
 47 | 
 48 | You can read on to see what he shared!
 49 | 
 50 | _Related:_ [_How the product team at TravelPerk runs sprints, performs retrospectives, and approaches integrations_](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-profiles-carlos-armas)
 51 | 
 52 | ### **Can you walk me through how you work with your CTO and engineers?**
 53 | 
 54 | I meet with my CTO on a bi-weekly cadence to talk through our priorities and next steps in taking the company vision and translating it to the product. This can be ideating net-new features we need to build and speccing them out with design, identifying existing features we should update, pinpointing bugs that need to be addressed, and so on.
 55 | 
 56 | Following these conversations, I build out the tickets in Jira and go on to have several meetings with our engineers during the first few days of the sprint. Throughout these meetings, the engineers can tell me if anything is unclear, what else I can provide to support them, and if they have any feedback on my ideas. In some cases, they’ll provide ideas that I didn’t even think were possible, or suggest more efficient solutions to a given problem. All of this to say, these calls are super collaborative, and we see developer feedback as an essential part of executing sprints successfully.
 57 | 
 58 | Once the engineers feel enabled to execute their tasks and go on to work on them, I QA the deliverables from the previous sprint, and by the end of that week I push them to production. So, just to clarify, our sprints are two weeks long, but the improvements and net-new features that come out of them go live by the end of the following week.
 59 | 
 60 | ### **What’s something you’ve done to level-up as a product manager?**
 61 | 
 62 | The last thing I want to be is the messenger, where I’d basically tell engineers that they need to do a certain task because so-and-so stakeholder wants it done.
 63 | 
 64 | I want to come into my conversations with engineers on a somewhat-level playing field and actually add value to the conversations. With that in mind, I’ve taken some coding classes to learn the coding language we use.
 65 | 
 66 | This has allowed me to better understand any issues they run up against, give them feedback on how to execute certain tasks, and feel more confident when confirming that we need certain tasks to get done within the current sprint.
 67 | 
 68 | Just to give you a quick example, API integrations are critical to our product. Before engaging with Merge, it was critical that I understood the technical nuances of API calls and payloads from specific 3rd-party applications. In addition, it was important to understand how the data from these payloads mapped back to our database.
 69 | 
 70 | The coding classes I took not only helped me grasp all of this but also understand specific issues and how to address them, like the prospect of payloads overwhelming our servers.
 71 | 
 72 | ### **How did you land on running two-week sprints?**
 73 | 
 74 | A lot of it has to do with how our product works, and I’d imagine that the answer is similar for PMs at other companies.
 75 | 
 76 | Our product is mobile-dependent, so while our users can send money or messages to colleagues via our web-based application, the beneficiaries would receive and accept the payments or messages via our mobile app.
 77 | 
 78 | We’ve found that iPhones release updates less frequently than Androids (our application is available on both devices), and, given the cadence with the former, we ultimately found that it didn’t make sense to release updates every week. Two weeks was perfect; it ensured that the updates kept pace with our team’s speed of innovation and it lined up well with Apple’s release schedule.
 79 | 
 80 | ### **What KPIs do you care about?**
 81 | 
 82 | It’s hard to gather customer feedback organically. Reason being, while our platform is critical to users, it isn’t necessarily going to inspire 5-star reviews. I like to compare us to Venmo in this scenario: Their users know that the application is invaluable to their day-to-day life, but you’d be hard pressed to find someone who actually feels compelled to write a review on the app.
 83 | 
 84 | With that said, product usage is really my north star. I like to check how much money is moving through our platform as well as how many messages get sent every day and week-over-week. As long as usage per user goes up on average, I’m generally happy.
 85 | 
 86 | Product usage also influences the majority of our feature enhancement decisions. For example, as we gain user data on withdrawals by channel (e.g. Paypal), we’ll follow the user data and allow that to inform our decisions. This can lead to creating quick actions for users to access funds instantly, allowing users to bank rewards for fewer volumes of transactions, among other potential enhancements.
 87 | 
 88 | ### **How have you approached building and maintaining product integrations?**
 89 | 
 90 | We’ve always known that product integrations are extremely important for us.
 91 | 
 92 | And while there are several ways that integrations can benefit our product, the ability to integrate employee rosters successfully across our clients’ HRIS solutions is probably the most important use case. Without a seamless integration, our clients would be forced to manually remove and add employees to our application every day; and considering that our clients naturally experience a lot of employee turnover, this can quickly turn into a nightmare.
 93 | 
 94 | We ended up using Merge to build several HRIS integrations and built daily roster syncs with our product. This has also allowed us to easily and accurately determine the number of active users in an account at a given point in time—enabling us to update our subscriptions with ease.
 95 | 
 96 | Now the proof is in the pudding: The integrations we’ve built with Merge have helped us prevent customer churn and have gone a long way in improving the customer experience.
 97 | 
 98 | _Want to learn more about Merge? You can_ [_schedule a demo with one of our integration experts_](https://www.merge.dev/get-in-touch?utm_btn=dr-page-blog%2Fproduct-profiles-noah-sclar) _to discover how our platform can help you integrate at scale._
 99 | 
100 | “It was the same process, go talk to their team, figure out their API. It was taking a lot of time. And then before we knew it, there was a laundry list of HR integrations being requested for our prospects and customers.”

 28 | # Product Profiles: Rahm Fehr, Senior Director of PM at Gong
 29 | 
 30 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67856c760b382a09b607210e_Customer_spotlight_-_Gong_-_Rahm_Fehr__1200x630_%2525252528Blog%2525252529_%25252525281%2525252529.webp)
 31 | 
 32 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cb26b36cc62374679f071f_Jon%20Gitlin%20-%20Merge.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/64dd538684e09763589291b7_64c13599abc4a993825ecd2d_Jon%2520Gitlin%2520headshot.webp)
 33 | 
 34 | Jon Gitlin
 35 | 
 36 | Senior Content Marketing Manager
 37 | 
 38 | @Merge
 39 | 
 40 | Welcome to another edition of “Product Profiles”, where product leaders share everything from how their teams are structured to how they release new features.
 41 | 
 42 | We were fortunate enough to chat with [Rahm Fehr](https://www.linkedin.com/in/rahmfehr/) from [Gong](https://www.gong.io/), a Revenue Intelligence Platform that uses proprietary AI technology to help GTM teams capture every customer interaction, understand it, and act on their learnings quickly and effectively.
 43 | 
 44 | Rahm is currently a Senior Director of Product Management and was the company's first Head of Product. He has a wealth of experience in product management, not only at Gong but also from his time at Verint and Kenshoo.
 45 | 
 46 | You can read on to learn more about Rahm and the product team at Gong!
 47 | 
 48 | ### **Can you tell me a little bit about your background at Gong?**
 49 | 
 50 | I’ve worked at Gong for just over 5 years now and spent the first couple of years leading the product function. Eventually, one of our co-founders (and my manager) decided that he wanted to focus solely on product management, so his role evolved from CTO to Chief Product Officer.
 51 | 
 52 | As our product function scaled, we added several groups under me that focused on key areas of our platform. This includes groups on Conversation Intelligence, Mobile, Data Capture, and Sales Assistance.
 53 | 
 54 | More recently, I’ve taken on an initiative that involves leveraging the Gong in other domains. I can’t say too much about this platform at the moment; suffice to say, it will serve a new audience and address additional pain points for GTM, as well as other teams.
 55 | 
 56 | _Related:_ [_How the product team at TravelPerk operates_](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-profiles-carlos-armas)
 57 | 
 58 | ### **How is the product team structured today?**
 59 | 
 60 | We work in pods that focus on a specific persona and/or use case; each pod has a product manager, team lead, developer(s), and a product designer. Several pods share an analyst and a writer.
 61 | 
 62 | A set of related pods makes up a group; each group solves a broader problem or use case, like deal management or sales engagement. The product group managers and other related units report to our CPO.
 63 | 
 64 | Outside of these groups, we have centrally-managed product design and analyst teams to ensure that the designers, writers, and analysts in the pods and groups are aligned. And we have a product operations function that builds out, monitors, and optimizes all of our processes. This includes how we capture and assign requests, approve specific plans, communicate with go-to-market teams, release new features, and so on. Their work ultimately takes a lot of work off of our product managers’ plates, allowing the PMs to focus on core parts of their role.
 65 | 
 66 | ### **Do your pods run sprints?**
 67 | 
 68 | We decided early on that we didn’t want to enforce specific processes for each pod; we felt that they should have the autonomy to work in the way that suits them best.
 69 | 
 70 | Also, to be frank, we don’t really believe in sprints. I’ve found that they force teams into one of two extremes: There’s either not enough to do during the sprint, leading the employees to experience quite a bit of down time; or there’s too much to do, which compromises the quality of execution.
 71 | 
 72 | That said, we do have certain requirements for our pods, mainly in areas that require collaborating with managers or a team outside the pod.
 73 | 
 74 | Each PM from a pod has to fill out a feature brief, which requires them to provide context on what they’re looking to solve, why, and how. In addition, they need to include insight from users that backs what they’re looking to accomplish, which they usually provide via actual snippets of conversation that’s recorded and analyzed in Gong. Once the PM provides all of this, other pod members (along with our leaders and complementary teams, like R&D) can review the briefs and provide their input on it.
 75 | 
 76 | We also have recurring planning meetings every quarter and year. Similar to the product brief, each PM from a pod has to provide context in a doc around what they’re looking to solve for the coming quarter (or year), why, and how. The PMs present these docs to management during the meetings, and management can provide approvals or constructive feedback—with the goal of having plans fully-approved before the coming quarter (or year).
 77 | 
 78 | Finally, we have monthly meetings between the group lead (along with the PMs and team leads of each pod and a few heads of specific functions) and the head of product and the head of R&D. They’ll use the time to assess their progress, discuss obstacles, opportunities, etc.
 79 | 
 80 | ### **How does Gong release new features?**
 81 | 
 82 | Gong continuously deploys product updates, but we open new features to customers on a monthly cadence to prevent overwhelming our GTM teams and clients.
 83 | 
 84 | We typically release a feature within Gong first, which gives us a chance to “drink our own champagne” and see if there are any kinks that need to be sorted out. Then, depending on the feature, its potential impact, and what we’re looking to learn, we may release it to a subset of clients. Once the associated PM is fully confident that the feature delivers its intended value, they push it to GA in coordination with our GTM partners, like product marketing and sales.
 85 | 
 86 | ### **How does Gong approach integrations?**
 87 | 
 88 | We didn’t have the best experience with the other unified API solutions we tried in the past, so we decided to build our integrations ourselves or with the help of partners. And at this point, it’s safe to say that we and our partners have built 140+ native integrations. This includes CRM systems, BI solutions, calendar tools, and other categories of software.
 89 | 
 90 | However, my current pod can’t afford to allocate resources to building and maintaining the integrations with our soon-to-be-released platform. We need our team to focus on building out the features and functionality that differentiates our platform and drives unique value to our clients.
 91 | 
 92 | That led us to try Merge roughly a year ago; and given the success we’ve seen so far in setting up the integrations through one of your unified APIs, we’re now looking to expand our usage of your platform; namely, we’re looking into adopting Merge’s [CRM Unified API](https://www.merge.dev/categories/crm-api).
 93 | 
 94 | ‍ _Want to learn more about Merge?_ [_Schedule a demo with one of our integration experts_](https://www.merge.dev/get-in-touch?utm_btn=dr-page-blog%2Fproduct-profiles-rahm-fehr) _to see the platform in action._
 95 | 
 96 | “It was the same process, go talk to their team, figure out their API. It was taking a lot of time. And then before we knew it, there was a laundry list of HR integrations being requested for our prospects and customers.”

 40 | # Product roadmap: examples, tips, and formats to consider
 41 | 
 42 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67d9ca5e423a87d4859f5726_AI%20product%20strategy.png)
 43 | 
 44 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cb1e10d897b1194792e1de_Anuj%20Jhunjhunwala%20-%20Merge.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/65ba8b5339e4c1931fb22629_anuj-headshot-2-min.webp)
 45 | 
 46 | Anuj Jhunjhunwala
 47 | 
 48 | Director of Product Management
 49 | 
 50 | @Merge
 51 | 
 52 | Building best-in-class products requires juggling short and long-term business needs with existing and planned resources effectively.
 53 | 
 54 | This juggling exercise can be incredibly complex when you’re dealing with several stakeholders, managing multiple product lines, and serving several types of customers. And this only gets exacerbated when you factor in competitive pressures, economic trends, and more.
 55 | 
 56 | To help you navigate this as effectively as possible, you can build a flexible, comprehensive product roadmap that your cross-functional teams and customers are aware of and bought into.
 57 | 
 58 | We’ll break down how you can build one by highlighting several noteworthy examples and by sharing tips for building your own.
 59 | 
 60 | But first, let’s align on the definition of a product roadmap.
 61 | 
 62 | ## **What is a product roadmap?**
 63 | 
 64 | It’s a visual summary that outlines the products, features, and functionality you plan to build or improve on in your platform. The roadmap can also be filterable by key themes, such as AI or security, to make it easy to skim and analyze.
 65 | 
 66 | [![A visualization of a product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6810fd2de5397297d3a37602_product%20roadmap.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6810fd2de5397297d3a37602_product%20roadmap.png)
 67 | 
 68 | A great product roadmap should be accessible for go-to-market and technical teams and be steeped in a strong understanding of the business goals, customer needs, and technical realities (e.g., available engineering resources).
 69 | 
 70 | [Related](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-objectives?blog-related=image)
 71 | 
 72 | #### [Product objectives: how to define yours successfully](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-objectives?blog-related=image)
 73 | 
 74 | [![Product objectives: how to define yours successfully](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cdd376071b615c9f2dcbcb_Blog%20Header%20Brand%20Refresh.png)](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-objectives?blog-related=image)
 75 | 
 76 | ## **Real product roadmap examples**
 77 | 
 78 | Here are just a few real-world examples of product roadmaps that are worth taking inspiration from.
 79 | 
 80 | ### **GitHub**
 81 | 
 82 | The developer platform offers a [public product roadmap](https://github.com/orgs/github/projects/4247/views/1) that—unsurprisingly—uses their own platform.
 83 | 
 84 | [![GitHub's public roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8efe9024ab8a69aecdf_AD_4nXcG-y7pz9ECFLg9Lnv2VgzBs8AfIiEMShh515G76xOk3ve-z7mC9W6ZsezNmyZppWlH0h6Q1kjX3O6xBj-X0jQEpCwzyrn-RqilvZ0bImJmeWjwIOYRKGxlEOPm6X-FMF5T1Lg3nA.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8efe9024ab8a69aecdf_AD_4nXcG-y7pz9ECFLg9Lnv2VgzBs8AfIiEMShh515G76xOk3ve-z7mC9W6ZsezNmyZppWlH0h6Q1kjX3O6xBj-X0jQEpCwzyrn-RqilvZ0bImJmeWjwIOYRKGxlEOPm6X-FMF5T1Lg3nA.png)
 85 | 
 86 | **Some areas worth highlighting:**
 87 | 
 88 | - Their roadmap items are broken down by product focus areas—”Accelerate with AI”, “Secure at every step”, “Platform for collaboration at scale”—so that you can quickly discover what’s being worked on and the status of a given initiative
 89 | 
 90 | 
 91 | - Each roadmap item includes a brief description on why the item is being worked on (“Value Prop”) and the expected benefits from working on it (“Expected Outcome”) to give you more context on the reasons why it’s important
 92 | 
 93 | [![Screenshot of specific item from GitHub's product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee91f338ed716dc2cd_AD_4nXc9Y8diemo4PStTeMd4ISouSZg9UUkh2lm6F5qhU8qzgYDgwK4RoHcy7ipYqVimpOAaYgBhoyLtVx8MKuMNOL5vuDBj_8UVgQ-dxDtymQtJ6fsa6J3PAT1qHJdJ65zSi-o68jYTqg.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee91f338ed716dc2cd_AD_4nXc9Y8diemo4PStTeMd4ISouSZg9UUkh2lm6F5qhU8qzgYDgwK4RoHcy7ipYqVimpOAaYgBhoyLtVx8MKuMNOL5vuDBj_8UVgQ-dxDtymQtJ6fsa6J3PAT1qHJdJ65zSi-o68jYTqg.png)
 94 | 
 95 | - Roadmap items are segmented by quarters and certain items are also featured in the “Future” column. This includes initiatives that are still being scoped
 96 | 
 97 | ‍
 98 | 
 99 | [![Status on a roadmap item](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eecdd5205730ba8a9b_AD_4nXc6jkAFN529MUGNYrX3bVzuv5-IiKk__YgIeIGZZYzv50-rgWxk1adGDJnsXTNsMLX64BcrZh7lyiORnlZgiTEjfV8BwMJKkDsXQec__LXFnNuVWva_6nYs_XKbGPuzlZQhXon_hg.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eecdd5205730ba8a9b_AD_4nXc6jkAFN529MUGNYrX3bVzuv5-IiKk__YgIeIGZZYzv50-rgWxk1adGDJnsXTNsMLX64BcrZh7lyiORnlZgiTEjfV8BwMJKkDsXQec__LXFnNuVWva_6nYs_XKbGPuzlZQhXon_hg.png)
100 | 
101 | _Many roadmap items in the “Future” column have a comment like the above to set expectations with stakeholders_
102 | 
103 | ### **Atlassian**
104 | 
105 | Atlassian, which offers a suite of solutions to help employees manage projects, find information, collaborate with one another, and more, offers a [comprehensive product roadmap across their cloud applications and data center solutions](https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/cloud).
106 | 
107 | ‍
108 | 
109 | [![Atlassian's product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed0628ed4605fa8db7_AD_4nXfDA9FEF_VD47oAJs4ygNsWOPjcG5Rz4oJ54lcG5blMDlxce0QdfzVLjWzGrR4AbxE2R4_M6O6Vsf3KRl2w9nEObg-NSdjmtXPBBqd1OTBh66SbZMnFk1qtQJNzkCHNA9NTE1pwWw.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed0628ed4605fa8db7_AD_4nXfDA9FEF_VD47oAJs4ygNsWOPjcG5Rz4oJ54lcG5blMDlxce0QdfzVLjWzGrR4AbxE2R4_M6O6Vsf3KRl2w9nEObg-NSdjmtXPBBqd1OTBh66SbZMnFk1qtQJNzkCHNA9NTE1pwWw.png)
110 | 
111 | **Some areas worth highlighting:**
112 | 
113 | - Atlassian promotes a quarterly newsletter that shares what they’ve released, what’s coming up, etc.
114 | 
115 | [![How Atlassian promotes their product newsletter](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed7d6f5dc4c0ba6c56_AD_4nXdGDywIBU7XbVifigttBcMv2f7cRA2wF5EYn91LDpCG9jrle6rff_eiEn8ulgTFfUrRJCKhuBOd3vHD2A9WCRO8F89nYeR0MRSf3zQ4BlHm-2dN6Hgy24bG21HRBQx48cm5IZMdBw.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed7d6f5dc4c0ba6c56_AD_4nXdGDywIBU7XbVifigttBcMv2f7cRA2wF5EYn91LDpCG9jrle6rff_eiEn8ulgTFfUrRJCKhuBOd3vHD2A9WCRO8F89nYeR0MRSf3zQ4BlHm-2dN6Hgy24bG21HRBQx48cm5IZMdBw.png)
116 | 
117 | - You can access advanced search functionality to find specific roadmap items quickly, whether that’s by using their search bar, filtering for a certain application (e.g., Jira), or selecting a certain status
118 | 
119 | [![Filter functionality for Atlassian's product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eec0f8d9dc111d5afa_AD_4nXdXDaSgsYA5b1dxgavLSZgb9iFdbVn9GIK6wlwd_Viawm3tyd7yj1iQDK6sVI7v5fRGeGQ-pGiJWVzVoxiqhCiEqzn5_YmgBYmSpvs1aYQUGqAbaYd9TPOJtfuWf6jbODUym-c.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eec0f8d9dc111d5afa_AD_4nXdXDaSgsYA5b1dxgavLSZgb9iFdbVn9GIK6wlwd_Viawm3tyd7yj1iQDK6sVI7v5fRGeGQ-pGiJWVzVoxiqhCiEqzn5_YmgBYmSpvs1aYQUGqAbaYd9TPOJtfuWf6jbODUym-c.png)
120 | 
121 | Since Atlassian offers so many applications, their “Apps” dropdown can be essential for customers that only use a specific solution
122 | 
123 | - If you click into a specific roadmap item, you can find a link to share it. This lets customers and prospects share the context, timeline, and status of a given initiative
124 | 
125 | [Related](https://www.merge.dev/blog/ai-product-strategy?blog-related=image)
126 | 
127 | #### [AI product strategy: key steps, examples, and best practices](https://www.merge.dev/blog/ai-product-strategy?blog-related=image)
128 | 
129 | [![AI product strategy: key steps, examples, and best practices](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67d9ca5e423a87d4859f5726_AI%20product%20strategy.png)](https://www.merge.dev/blog/ai-product-strategy?blog-related=image)
130 | 
131 | ### **Microsoft 365**
132 | 
133 | Microsoft 365 includes several widely-used productivity applications (e.g., Microsoft Word) and cloud services (e.g., OneDrive) and security features.
134 | 
135 | Like Atlassian, their product roadmap offers advanced search capabilities to help customers and prospects find relevant updates, quickly.
136 | 
137 | [![Microsoft 365's roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee47401d251eb66227_AD_4nXdRoS8IS1dCfUsjNeFep4ymdhSMzSz8tQeCRSgZI7Kh_TbNxyMMqbzg_1F0dG8ytgO_kC9r3UYoN_rBz48wW8JK9N4VqGF4RvkYNMPiTr3fQJjbOme-96eFQM6Dc08wPF9Pb20f7w.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee47401d251eb66227_AD_4nXdRoS8IS1dCfUsjNeFep4ymdhSMzSz8tQeCRSgZI7Kh_TbNxyMMqbzg_1F0dG8ytgO_kC9r3UYoN_rBz48wW8JK9N4VqGF4RvkYNMPiTr3fQJjbOme-96eFQM6Dc08wPF9Pb20f7w.png)
138 | 
139 | **Some areas worth highlighting:**
140 | 
141 | - Each roadmap item includes two types of dates to clarify their level of availability—”Preview Available” and “Rollout Start”
142 | 
143 | [![How Microsoft 3365 clarifies status of a roadmap item](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee2d9fec39e201abf8_AD_4nXeA0AUoG5Eum3iuO62C-jtXL_M5tA4lRs1v_MbxNzY1fMAX3oGITt_QUvFeZQkzBtxTcR-1fxivfFetAniiixaQLPScC2Q0ojQ9-xwX5N1O40XXXo3buDMIcivcpBgDy54gEXiD.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee2d9fec39e201abf8_AD_4nXeA0AUoG5Eum3iuO62C-jtXL_M5tA4lRs1v_MbxNzY1fMAX3oGITt_QUvFeZQkzBtxTcR-1fxivfFetAniiixaQLPScC2Q0ojQ9-xwX5N1O40XXXo3buDMIcivcpBgDy54gEXiD.png)
144 | 
145 | - You can download the entire roadmap in a CSV file—which includes feature names, their details, their statuses, and more—to easily share specific items with colleagues
146 | 
147 | [![How Microsoft 365 lets you download their roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eec11544adaf8b25ee_AD_4nXcZwdXGW-eVHB2HvKjt3MDtX-wkzv6OahO8BshDmMlWoQdL36Mx73_QR-A25rqROB_4ofQa5rkNdAu_uf3KdLIIDj4_R7u55uT1T4J1m9CBgw8Dlf2WyptoK2R6-e7WWOUsAWRy.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eec11544adaf8b25ee_AD_4nXcZwdXGW-eVHB2HvKjt3MDtX-wkzv6OahO8BshDmMlWoQdL36Mx73_QR-A25rqROB_4ofQa5rkNdAu_uf3KdLIIDj4_R7u55uT1T4J1m9CBgw8Dlf2WyptoK2R6-e7WWOUsAWRy.png)
148 | 
149 | - You can click into a roadmap item to get a comprehensive breakdown of what’s being built or improved
150 | 
151 | [![How Microsoft 365 includes descriptions in their roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eda5a1f7922fc0e4e9_AD_4nXdisv7g7wyNHDlbU4k8PUHFFqNdefh5sSoLHWj02G5FEMcDEbTXPZNh081CBZJofjejgf1N-lT9c5r2SKUC_mRWfZvTLowM4RaMcOb2EyZWJI7xHymJCOmjDF1eYEv-C9aO_CVz2g.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eda5a1f7922fc0e4e9_AD_4nXdisv7g7wyNHDlbU4k8PUHFFqNdefh5sSoLHWj02G5FEMcDEbTXPZNh081CBZJofjejgf1N-lT9c5r2SKUC_mRWfZvTLowM4RaMcOb2EyZWJI7xHymJCOmjDF1eYEv-C9aO_CVz2g.png)
152 | 
153 | [Related](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-experience-strategy?blog-related=image)
154 | 
155 | #### [How to build a product experience (PX) strategy in 2025](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-experience-strategy?blog-related=image)
156 | 
157 | [![How to build a product experience (PX) strategy in 2025](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67d857c228f210c3289347ec_Blog%20Header%20Brand%20Refresh%20(5).png)](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-experience-strategy?blog-related=image)
158 | 
159 | ### **HubSpot**
160 | 
161 | The company, which offers customer service, marketing, and sales software, offers product roadmaps for each product offering via slides. They include a “Currently In Development” section alongside a “Being Planned” section.
162 | 
163 | [![HubSpot Service Hub product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8effb4513c27f2af4c3_AD_4nXfpT8AFwsQ2xQZxAcRoB8eFwZsRmvudI_xGF9YbeXtrBhZ2PLignhp6S0DtzJvZos0vd_ABMCO6PM-BWhGRPRmylI8xYDiiE2bfb-GWK9rODtp1hgMHwFQBDYBQnjV4Wz844WyKQA.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8effb4513c27f2af4c3_AD_4nXfpT8AFwsQ2xQZxAcRoB8eFwZsRmvudI_xGF9YbeXtrBhZ2PLignhp6S0DtzJvZos0vd_ABMCO6PM-BWhGRPRmylI8xYDiiE2bfb-GWK9rODtp1hgMHwFQBDYBQnjV4Wz844WyKQA.png)
164 | 
165 | _How the product roadmap looks for HubSpot’s Service Hub™_
166 | 
167 | **Some areas worth highlighting:**
168 | 
169 | - HubSpot offers a “Share your ideas” CTA that leads you to a landing page where you can both view product ideas for certain HubSpot products and submit your own
170 | 
171 | [![How HubSpot lets you share product ideas](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8edd3217e68eb921a8c_AD_4nXf4lmMgn4I24fmJuKUo4ZalSJ3Y8Wp-TmRicE_WppI8iv4bXSxXR4FmYyc-pksAxCGg0jFtuBxxesPm2WrKCQ4MKOyK68yWA9eKYS4rlYjofLq6zQ4IMOAIr8LNWPgZSGSbqYFV.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8edd3217e68eb921a8c_AD_4nXf4lmMgn4I24fmJuKUo4ZalSJ3Y8Wp-TmRicE_WppI8iv4bXSxXR4FmYyc-pksAxCGg0jFtuBxxesPm2WrKCQ4MKOyK68yWA9eKYS4rlYjofLq6zQ4IMOAIr8LNWPgZSGSbqYFV.png)
172 | 
173 | - You can easily find previous product updates (their product roadmap only shows future enhancements or builds) by clicking into their release notes or product updates deck
174 | 
175 | [![How HubSpot promotes their release notes and monthly product updates](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed0ab2ba0b3fdc9e8f_AD_4nXdR00Rr9iRWSnfIvQmV5vgLHTjbRnpGo7N_afYpKLZWyguezbdEjLD3WFzIgqmIQ4Bf3uNmH8WpAFRqzM0TKgaOmmuBVFMEy4Sje9_Q5zR9cNsMVSfYeSqfE7wXPeRS7lM5Xaeifg.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed0ab2ba0b3fdc9e8f_AD_4nXdR00Rr9iRWSnfIvQmV5vgLHTjbRnpGo7N_afYpKLZWyguezbdEjLD3WFzIgqmIQ4Bf3uNmH8WpAFRqzM0TKgaOmmuBVFMEy4Sje9_Q5zR9cNsMVSfYeSqfE7wXPeRS7lM5Xaeifg.png)
176 | 
177 | ### **Ahrefs**
178 | 
179 | The SEO software’s roadmap uses 3 stages for each initiative: “Planned”, “In Progress”, and “Complete”.
180 | 
181 | [![Ahref's product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eeb5568474a470e37e_AD_4nXcpBQ6mjgEZaDluT2A8G2XEgnpQ1lu6g9ZgAlWzmT-sZ1UB79nawxqbOUFnWNM3hYNa-z60SdeoeREWUvTUqIX9Dpg1RMgSaLhhRv11fQkXcul2rLvWrhrdDahnDDFw9f0ClpMC4Q.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eeb5568474a470e37e_AD_4nXcpBQ6mjgEZaDluT2A8G2XEgnpQ1lu6g9ZgAlWzmT-sZ1UB79nawxqbOUFnWNM3hYNa-z60SdeoeREWUvTUqIX9Dpg1RMgSaLhhRv11fQkXcul2rLvWrhrdDahnDDFw9f0ClpMC4Q.png)
182 | 
183 | **Some areas worth highlighting:**
184 | 
185 | - Ahrefs lets you upvote the roadmap items you’re most interested in—giving the Ahrefs team a better understanding of what customers want most
186 | 
187 | [![Upvoted roadmap items that are "In Progress"](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee35d67b96d7e04b24_AD_4nXf1UMeOvBD18Y9yJivUA79trMo4Z9WBFuW5Jn4iKwAZ91AGZklRYKrN-uccXiTqqreIbxME3lSmq8Dmg9tr5Nevn2lC9XBDhFOgtsSVLCTGIcAlrZAQHxqtvIsfXO3uAsDZZCRb.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee35d67b96d7e04b24_AD_4nXf1UMeOvBD18Y9yJivUA79trMo4Z9WBFuW5Jn4iKwAZ91AGZklRYKrN-uccXiTqqreIbxME3lSmq8Dmg9tr5Nevn2lC9XBDhFOgtsSVLCTGIcAlrZAQHxqtvIsfXO3uAsDZZCRb.png)
188 | 
189 | _The last item in the screenshot above is, clearly, most in-demand_
190 | 
191 | - Anyone can comment on the roadmap items, which can lead to helpful context from customers on why a product ask is important
192 | 
193 | [![How Ahrefs lets users comment on roadmap items](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed825fddb7dfc71c9d_AD_4nXfvG6w0ysuRIcbNnrYJRKB2R4dauO9Vs4MpcF0zhZINX8RHDOQXwpUwSf7Eu5MD8rcx8-v8sDYqHrPLMCpUpN8lLKRAFE43KH-b6E3a79UMakEts98aq6iIgjXGODHLPEq8G1tFig.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ed825fddb7dfc71c9d_AD_4nXfvG6w0ysuRIcbNnrYJRKB2R4dauO9Vs4MpcF0zhZINX8RHDOQXwpUwSf7Eu5MD8rcx8-v8sDYqHrPLMCpUpN8lLKRAFE43KH-b6E3a79UMakEts98aq6iIgjXGODHLPEq8G1tFig.png)
194 | 
195 | ## **Types of product roadmaps (and when to use each)**
196 | 
197 | As our examples showed, product roadmaps can use several formats.
198 | 
199 | Here are some of the most common types of roadmaps you’ll want to evaluate.
200 | 
201 | ### **Timeline-based roadmap**
202 | 
203 | This type of roadmap clearly shows when roadmap items are started, worked on, and finished.
204 | 
205 | GitHub’s product roadmap is just one of many examples. (they present timeframes by quarters).
206 | 
207 | [![Screenshot of GitHub's product roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fd4720f1447d44305dda3_Screenshot%202025-04-28%20at%203.17.35%E2%80%AFPM.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fd4720f1447d44305dda3_Screenshot%202025-04-28%20at%203.17.35%E2%80%AFPM.png)
208 | 
209 | Time-based roadmaps are popular for good reason: They help cross-functional teams, customers, and prospects quickly understand the timelines for different initiatives, which is one of the main reasons why a product roadmap exists to begin with.
210 | 
211 | This kind of roadmap may not, however, answer high-level questions, like what specific roadmap items aim to accomplish or how a given item fits within the broader product strategy. So if you’re looking to use a product roadmap as a way to drive internal and/or external discussion and buy-in, this may not be the best approach.
212 | 
213 | ### **Now-next-later roadmap**
214 | 
215 | This roadmap format is relatively new and more niche. The way it works is simple: You’d categorize roadmap items into one of three buckets: now, next, or later.
216 | 
217 | For each item, you can also include relevant tags to help people find them faster, the overarching business goals they support, and whether an item is internal and/or external-facing.
218 | 
219 | Here’s an example of how it can look [according to the CEO and co-founder of ProdPad](https://www.prodpad.com/blog/invented-now-next-later-roadmap/):
220 | 
221 | [![Example of now-next-later roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee2b3b4d2652b5678b_AD_4nXd_oM9yOO51PXDDiigMPsKXS4PJwAoV6tnsBsSJkk-SXJjb_m8s9HL6dInbVpjPCsLl3uxB8GLYm2sedSAB-Kf0iaHMj0_jG_vs7fXEKVjmzcxjaJsIUP9QxrVUjXJwBJWQ5zw5.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8ee2b3b4d2652b5678b_AD_4nXd_oM9yOO51PXDDiigMPsKXS4PJwAoV6tnsBsSJkk-SXJjb_m8s9HL6dInbVpjPCsLl3uxB8GLYm2sedSAB-Kf0iaHMj0_jG_vs7fXEKVjmzcxjaJsIUP9QxrVUjXJwBJWQ5zw5.png)
222 | 
223 | One of the benefits of this approach is its simplicity: Readers can immediately tell what’s being worked on and why.
224 | 
225 | But it invites open-ended questions, like “When is a project in ‘Next’ going to be worked on?”, and “What does later mean?” So if you’re looking to provide a roadmap that doesn’t require additional context or follow ups, this may not be the approach to take.
226 | 
227 | [Related](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-management-tools?blog-related=image)
228 | 
229 | #### [Product management tools for 2025: what to use and why](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-management-tools?blog-related=image)
230 | 
231 | [![Product management tools for 2025: what to use and why](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cdd376071b615c9f2dcbcb_Blog%20Header%20Brand%20Refresh.png)](https://www.merge.dev/blog/product-management-tools?blog-related=image)
232 | 
233 | ### **Theme-based roadmap**
234 | 
235 | This type of roadmap breaks down roadmap items by themes.
236 | 
237 | Going back to our GitHub example, they adopt a theme-based roadmap by bucketing their roadmap items into the following filterable themes: AI, security, and collaboration.
238 | 
239 | ‍
240 | 
241 | [![Example of theme-based roadmap](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eef2083fabbfdb4678_AD_4nXcGhIOv9QzaWUpKyXO2etsoaAAO_A6nT-BxJ3rvMGxGF9oarlQRshQsc6ECYUKgd7loGBmlUVvjc3FvryVOxLRgmTkznXI8B9K028NZR_oCMb5aQ9wxqDsa7O37sTPpeu1cIb33ag.png)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/680fc8eef2083fabbfdb4678_AD_4nXcGhIOv9QzaWUpKyXO2etsoaAAO_A6nT-BxJ3rvMGxGF9oarlQRshQsc6ECYUKgd7loGBmlUVvjc3FvryVOxLRgmTkznXI8B9K028NZR_oCMb5aQ9wxqDsa7O37sTPpeu1cIb33ag.png)
242 | 
243 | This approach lets your readers easily analyze roadmap items within a certain theme. It also provides a high-level understanding of the product’s strategic goals.
244 | 
245 | That said, themes, in and of themselves, aren’t enough. You’ll likely also want to specify when certain roadmap items are being worked on, the specific goals each item supports, etc.
246 | 
247 | ## **Best practices for creating and managing your roadmap**
248 | 
249 | Even if you adopt a proven product roadmap format and follow successful examples, your roadmap might not be effective if you don’t follow the best practices below.
250 | 
251 | ### **Collaborate with engineering early and often**
252 | 
253 | Your engineering team has the insights you need to develop and continually refine your roadmap. This includes:
254 | 
255 | - How long and how many resources certain roadmap items will take to execute
256 | - Whether a given roadmap item is more complex and time-intensive than expected
257 | - If a certain roadmap item has dependencies that require you to add additional items and/or reprioritize your roadmap
258 | 
259 | To stay on top of your engineering team’s experiences and ensure you’re leveraging their expertise consistently, you’ll need to consistently ask for feedback during your recurring sprint syncs, retrospectives, backlog refinement sessions, and other meetings with them.
260 | 
261 | You can make your partnership with engineering even more consistent and structured by setting up a bot in an app like Slack that asks for status updates on specific roadmap items, along with open-ended questions on how things are going to get their candid feedback.
262 | 
263 | ### **Build in flexibility**
264 | 
265 | As the quick and fast rise of large language models (LLMs) showed, innovation can be quick, aggressive, and in many cases, affect your business and/or customers.
266 | 
267 | To help your team be agile and opportunistic when trends—like LLMs—impact your product, you should set the expectation with all of your stakeholders that the product roadmap isn’t fixed but a living, breathing resource that should adapt to your customers’ and prospects’ needs over time.
268 | 
269 | ### **Tie initiatives to strategic goals**
270 | 
271 | Nearly all of our product roadmap examples did a great job of tying initiatives to broader business goals.
272 | 
273 | That isn’t by accident.
274 | 
275 | Most employees and customers who review your roadmap won’t be familiar with individual roadmap items but they'll probably understand your broader product goals. As a result, making this connection helps your colleagues and customers better understand why something is being done and why it is or is not a priority.
276 | 
277 | ### **Surface external dependencies clearly**
278 | 
279 | Many roadmap items require external parties to follow through on a commitment.
280 | 
281 | For example, if you plan to integrate your product with a certain API provider’s endpoint when they plan to make it available, you’re depending on that API provider to actually make it available when they said they would.
282 | 
283 | Whenever you depend on an external party to help execute a roadmap initiative, you should make explicit note of it. That way, if the 3rd-party does fail to deliver on time, your customers and colleagues can easily learn why and won’t be quick to blame you.
284 | 
285 | ### **Review and revise often**
286 | 
287 | As mentioned earlier, your product roadmap can and should evolve alongside your business’ and customers’ needs.
288 | 
289 | To keep your roadmap relevant and effective, you should review it on a cadence that lets you make timely adjustments. For larger companies in relatviely stable markets, this can be once per quarter; while smaller companies in faster-changing markets may want to revisit it as often as every month.
290 |

302 | 
303 | Merge also lets you avoid maintaining any of the integrations afterwards and provides integration observability features to help your customer-facing teams manage integrations themselves.

 30 | # 3 recent product releases that enable our customers to provide global, enterprise-grade integrations
 31 | 
 32 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cdd376071b615c9f2dcbcb_Blog%20Header%20Brand%20Refresh.png)
 33 | 
 34 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67cb26b36cc62374679f071f_Jon%20Gitlin%20-%20Merge.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/64dd538684e09763589291b7_64c13599abc4a993825ecd2d_Jon%2520Gitlin%2520headshot.webp)
 35 | 
 36 | Jon Gitlin
 37 | 
 38 | Senior Content Marketing Manager
 39 | 
 40 | @Merge
 41 | 
 42 | Our team is constantly releasing new security features, additional integrations, enhanced syncing capabilities, and more to help customers add reliable, flexible, and secure integrations to their products.
 43 | 
 44 | We highlighted several of these releases during our inaugural webinar, “ [The Product Update](https://www.merge.dev/webinars/the-product-update-with-merge-fall-2024).”
 45 | 
 46 | Here’s just a snapshot of some of the features we covered and that we hope you can leverage.
 47 | 
 48 | ### **Onboard customers around the world to Merge’s integrations with Link Localization**
 49 | 
 50 | Many of our customers work with organizations in different regions. As a result, they’d need to offer [Merge Link](https://docs.merge.dev/get-started/link/)—a UI component that lets users authenticate and authorize their integrations—in different languages.
 51 | 
 52 | To meet this need, we’ve built Link Localization, which can automatically translate the Merge Link interface to another language for a specific customer(s).
 53 | 
 54 | Link Localization is already available in German, but we’re set to release it in French and Spanish within weeks, and we’ll add additional languages over the coming months.
 55 | 
 56 | [![Merge Link visualizations for English, German, and French](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459b8d336d77d5236a3a_AD_4nXfIstF289x8rJJIVgS2FhhvY6QoJ3k6rkG9GaIN1u3LvMwMYyWKwPms_gBw-5dVPNaNFi-H4m8YRpBJyTYxV54-3YL7l-UNedaaNsirQODZDSXHI2oKmB0Aac3_kVqwT2wKvf8RNDPS_kfQ4Nv-yhDelRKA.webp)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459b8d336d77d5236a3a_AD_4nXfIstF289x8rJJIVgS2FhhvY6QoJ3k6rkG9GaIN1u3LvMwMYyWKwPms_gBw-5dVPNaNFi-H4m8YRpBJyTYxV54-3YL7l-UNedaaNsirQODZDSXHI2oKmB0Aac3_kVqwT2wKvf8RNDPS_kfQ4Nv-yhDelRKA.webp)
 57 | 
 58 | _‍_
 59 | 
 60 | Learn more about [Link Localization](https://www.merge.dev/localization).
 61 | 
 62 | ### **Offer a best-in-class FP&A solution with our general ledger endpoint**
 63 | 
 64 | To support customers in the financial planning and analysis (FP&A) space, we’re adding a general ledger endpoint to accounting integrations.
 65 | 
 66 | This will allow our customers to access all the transactions that affect their clients’ general ledgers. In turn, our FP&A customers can power up-to-date, personalized, and actionable forecasts as well as help users plan for a wide range of scenarios effectively.
 67 | 
 68 | [![GL endpoint visualization](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459be9a2a3a55e2d2af0_AD_4nXcHxah35KjRAZEbrRSFdjAe_8Jk6RXW6w7UDBAixYJKI76e7v_wZGpLdiU2UWOlYrrOdDW5beUPCDABwnaOPRQvxc8dpHAsHwTwMGGyFEHaS5Zj3Ow2mMuLpk1Mq8JheH9kEoxSkegpJ8vKBbILgonXoic2.webp)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459be9a2a3a55e2d2af0_AD_4nXcHxah35KjRAZEbrRSFdjAe_8Jk6RXW6w7UDBAixYJKI76e7v_wZGpLdiU2UWOlYrrOdDW5beUPCDABwnaOPRQvxc8dpHAsHwTwMGGyFEHaS5Zj3Ow2mMuLpk1Mq8JheH9kEoxSkegpJ8vKBbILgonXoic2.webp)
 69 | 
 70 | The endpoint is slated to go live for several accounting integrations soon, including Xero, Sage Intacct, QuickBooks Online, and NetSuite.
 71 | 
 72 | If you’re an existing customer, you can learn more about it by connecting with your dedicated CSM; otherwise, you can [schedule a demo with one of our integration experts](https://www.merge.dev/get-in-touch?utm_btn=dr-page-blog%2Fproduct-update-fall).
 73 | 
 74 | ### **Deliver a seamless onboarding experience by personalizing Merge Link**
 75 | 
 76 | As your customers add integrations via Merge Link, you’ll likely want the experience to feel like a natural extension of your platform.
 77 | 
 78 | With this in mind, we’ve added several features that let you customize Merge Link.
 79 | 
 80 | You can, for example, pick and choose Merge Link’s font type and colors to match your brand’s look and feel.
 81 | 
 82 | [![How to customize Merge Link in our Dashboard](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459ace37ee43f226ac45_AD_4nXe_YG97E-8Db7gf6GfeL99PQCrcok2zJ3Z22_Gku_mBPoII5LpwIRLbYiRjAvCgIm_iRROSyvvL1Cqv7IZy_1a8DM7QWmihZ8apeHlGMRZj5k9kRFv7JGeOzEizg5-UK2t3lk-2WQmAKleg6g64kLLHPu8O.webp)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459ace37ee43f226ac45_AD_4nXe_YG97E-8Db7gf6GfeL99PQCrcok2zJ3Z22_Gku_mBPoII5LpwIRLbYiRjAvCgIm_iRROSyvvL1Cqv7IZy_1a8DM7QWmihZ8apeHlGMRZj5k9kRFv7JGeOzEizg5-UK2t3lk-2WQmAKleg6g64kLLHPu8O.webp)
 83 | 
 84 | You can also white label any of the user guides we’ve built in our help center and that we link out to from Merge Link. This includes adding your logo to the top of these pages and using your own subdomain.
 85 | 
 86 | [![How to whitelabel Merge Link and our help center guides](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459a50753367a3685074_AD_4nXf8sdbhidMwnaKCeZW7TW3GcsXyFZNzXCafANkaXPeeqvkmXPfDOdIFCYgJg97Wb3CqpcI4fKaffseZzzqKATG_HJP6lADRRAFAg_hrx5_sKHnCkYIfTmgEzvrgHIuUX4p30p6MZKumxdv_B4ogBjGvefY3.webp)](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6722459a50753367a3685074_AD_4nXf8sdbhidMwnaKCeZW7TW3GcsXyFZNzXCafANkaXPeeqvkmXPfDOdIFCYgJg97Wb3CqpcI4fKaffseZzzqKATG_HJP6lADRRAFAg_hrx5_sKHnCkYIfTmgEzvrgHIuUX4p30p6MZKumxdv_B4ogBjGvefY3.webp)
 87 | 
 88 | Learn more about white labeling Merge’s authentication guides in [our Docs](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/9683479-can-i-white-label-merge-s-authentication-guides).
 89 | 
 90 | ### **Final thoughts**
 91 | 
 92 | These product updates are just scratching the surface of what we’ve built and improved on over the past few months.
 93 | 
 94 | Our team broke down additional product features and capabilities we’ve added and plan to add during the webinar; and a few customers even shared how they’re using several of our recently-released features to enhance their product integrations.
 95 |

831 | ## Love for Merge
832 |

751 | Accounts
752 | 
753 | An Account represents a category in a company’s ledger in which a financial transaction is recorded against. The aggregation of each Account object is often referred to as the Chart of Accounts.
754 | 
755 | An Account can be classified into one of the following categories, determined through the classification field:
756 | Asset:\_\_ Accounts Receivable and Bank Accounts
757 | Liability:\_\_ Accounts Payable and Credit Card Accounts
758 | Equity:\_\_ Treasury Accounts and Retained Earnings
759 | Revenue:\_\_ Income and Other Income
760 | Expense:\_\_ Cost of Goods Sold and Office Expenses

 330 | ## Rate-limit management for passthrough requests
 331 | 
 332 | Merge has expanded rate limit management to include passthrough requests. Now when you're close to hitting a third-party rate limit, Merge will return a 400 error: “ `Third-party API provider rate limit exceeded. Please try again later.`” as a warning. This helps protect your linked account's functionality and prevents delays when making any passthrough requests.

 462 | ## Announcing our Merge Model Context Protocol (MCP)!
 463 | 
 464 | MCP is quickly becoming the go-to standard for connecting large language models (LLMs) to external data sources. This is why we’re so excited to announce Merge MCP!
 465 | 
 466 | Merge Model Context Protocol (MCP) allows your AI assistant to quickly and intelligently take real actions in your customers’ third-party platforms — whether that’s updating tickets, reading files, or creating journal entries.
 467 | 
 468 | Through just a few lines of code, Merge MCP enables your AI Agent to access hundreds of tools (actions) via a single MCP server.
 469 | 
 470 | Check out our [docs](https://docs.merge.dev/basics/mcp/) and our [GitHub](https://github.com/merge-api/merge-mcp) on how to implement Merge MCP!

 748 | ## New Accounting Common Models: Payment Terms and Payment Methods

1397 | # 🔁
1398 | 
1399 | ## Merge supports idempotency for accounting integrations
1400 | 
1401 | With idempotency, Merge allows you to safely retry POST requests without creating duplicate records. This allows for more resilient, scalable integrations, minimizing duplicate requests and supporting asynchronous processing for heavier tasks.
1402 | 
1403 | How it works:
1404 | 
1405 | - Use an idempotency key with each POST request
1406 | - If the same key is reused within 24 hours, no new request is processed — instead, the original response is returned instantly
1407 | 
1408 | You can learn more [here](https://docs.merge.dev/basics/idempotency/). This feature currently is in beta so please reach out to your account representative or [contact us](mailto: support@merge.dev) for more information.

1934 | ## SFTP observability and error handling
1935 | 
1936 | We now surface SFTP-specific errors directly in our dashboard (under [Issues](https://app.merge.dev/issues?status=ONGOING&utm_source=hs_email&utm_medium=email&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--evBVwbVGnuFOwF7ABYcY_UIONHH2qiULHGIY5BTl3uwzQyG2YIFJ0y9MoJEkiXUssf4Fw)). This provides you guidance on what the exact issue is when an SFTP does not successfully upload, making it easier to troubleshoot. The 4 types of errors that are surfaced are:
1937 | 
1938 | - Wrong file type
1939 | - Wrong file name
1940 | - Missing required fields
1941 | - Incorrectly formatted rows

2068 | # 🐚
2069 | 
2070 | ## Shell data filtering
2071 | 
2072 | Merge now automatically detects and hides newly created shell data records, ensuring incomplete data doesn’t appear anymore.
2073 | 
2074 | Shell data records are objects where most fields are null except metadata (e.g., IDs and timestamps). Shell data can be temporarily created due to the ordering of model syncs.
2075 | 
2076 | If you do need shell data records, be sure to include the query parameter `include_shell_data=True` when requesting data.
2077 | 
2078 | Shell object references will still be returned on any related non-shell objects, even without including the `include_shell_data=true parameter` (e.g., the UUID for a shell Location object will still display on a corresponding non-shell Employee object).
2079 | 
2080 | You can learn more [here](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/9713879-what-is-shell-data-filtering)! If you have any further questions, please reach out to your CSM or [support@merge.dev](mailto:support@merge.dev).

2221 | ## SFTP is now available!
2222 | 
2223 | Give your customers the option to securely transfer files and CSV reports between third-party platforms and Merge.
2224 | 
2225 | - Your customers receive step-by-step guidance on how to automate reports to a secure Merge-hosted SFTP server in Merge Link

2227 | - SFTP is currently available for select HRIS and ATS integrations
2228 | 
2229 | Learn more about how Merge SFTP can help your customers sync data via files automatically or manually [here](https://www.merge.dev/blog/merge-sftp).

3003 | ## Merge has established an official partnership with Rippling
3004 | 
3005 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/665a330b73a16acedbd039b1_Rippling%20annonucement%20(2).jpg)
3006 |

3008 | 
3009 | Merge is the first unified API solution to formally partner with Rippling and we see this as a big milestone in supporting our clients’ HRIS integration needs.
3010 |

3012 | 
3013 | # 🖇️
3014 | 
3015 | ## New linking flow step for admin-required HR & ATS integrations
3016 | 
3017 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6660bf66ec4014b7f09cd5db_Admin%20check.webp)
3018 | 
3019 | For admin-required HR & ATS integrations, an initial screen will now appear in Merge Link to inform your users they must be an admin of that third-party platform to successfully link. There is also a Magic Link URL that your user can share with the relevant admin, improving the overall user experience auth process!
3020 | 
3021 | # 🗾
3022 | 
3023 | ## New Field Mapping capabilities
3024 | 
3025 | [Field Mapping](https://docs.merge.dev/supplemental-data/field-mappings/overview/) is a flagship feature, enabling you and your customers to map custom data to Merge’s Common Models. We’ve expanded it’s functionality, making it even more powerful and intuitive.
3026 | 
3027 | - [**Advanced Mapping**](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/9269164-advanced-field-mapping-with-jmespath): Map any custom fields in a “list” or “object” format is now supported! Use JMESPath queries to access specific values from even the most complicated remote field objects.
3028 | - **Field Coverage:** Easily identify the correct remote field from a customer's account to use when mapping custom fields. Field coverage is a percentage estimate of how often a specific remote field appears for a specific Linked Account. The higher the coverage, the more widely it is used.
3029 | - **Preview Values:** Preview and validate that your Field Mapping is accurate before going live. Plug in any Common Model ID to check its return value in the Merge Dashboard.
3030 | 
3031 | These features are all now available on our Professional and Enterprise plans. Try them out today and let us know if you have any feedback!

3518 | 
3519 | ## Enhancements to Field Mapping by surfacing coverage percentage
3520 | 
3521 | We’re continuing to invest in our Field Mapping feature, and have pushed out new functionality to help you identify the best remote field from a customer’s account to leverage!
3522 | 
3523 | We now show the coverage percentage of each remote field, which is a calculation of how often the specific field is returned with a non-null value across that individual linked account.
3524 | 
3525 | For example, if you’re looking to map a specific field mapping for our Employee Object, we will show the coverage for each remote field available for mapping, and how often it is a non-null value for Employees.
3526 | 
3527 | This enhancement will give you more confidence that you are mapping the correct and most valuable field from a third-party system for a given field mapping!
3528 | 
3529 | Access it through the Linked Accounts view in our Dashboard, under the Field Mappings tab.
3530 | 
3531 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/66201e9365d9f3f36c052c05_Field%20Mapping%20coverage%20%25.png)

5117 | 
5118 | ## Account Linked Webhook and Common Model Synced Webhook
5119 | 
5120 | Our new [Merge Webhooks](https://docs.merge.dev/basics/webhooks/merge-webhooks/), Account Linked and Common Model Synced, are improved webhooks to accurately and reliably notify you when initial and following syncs are complete, ensuring that data is ready to be pulled.
5121 | 
5122 | - The Account Linked webhook will notify you when one of your customers create a new linked account, passing along the necessary account token.
5123 | - The Common Model Synced webhook will alert you when that specific Common Model and related fields for a linked account is initially synced and updated after that.

5557 | ## Migrating to our Advanced SDKs
5558 | 
5559 | We’re so excited to be releasing our Advanced SDKs for [Python](https://github.com/merge-api/merge-python-client/), [Java](https://github.com/merge-api/merge-java-client/), [Node](https://github.com/merge-api/merge-node-client/), and [Go](https://github.com/merge-api/merge-go-client/) to speed up your backend integration with Merge!

5616 | ## Async Passthrough is available in open beta
5617 | 
5618 | [Async passthrough](https://docs.merge.dev/supplemental-data/passthrough/async-passthrough/) allows you to retrieve the response at a later time. We built this feature since third-party response times differ and can cause delays for when calling passthrough requests.
5619 | 
5620 | With async passthrough you won't have to wait for a response before calling other requests or endpoints! We’ll also notify you through a webhook when your response is ready.
5621 | 
5622 | Learn more [here](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/8032634-async-passthrough#h_a5c8d26dc3).

5750 | ## File Storage is now in general availability!
5751 | 
5752 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/6410d75f475ba344a690149e_File%20Storage%20Integrations.png)
5753 | 
5754 | Our 7th Unified API category, File Storage, is now widely available.
5755 | 
5756 | File Storage currently supports 5 integrations: Google Drive, Dropbox, Box, SharePoint, and OneDrive.
5757 | 
5758 | Access real-time, normalized data for files, folders, drives, to power different use cases such as automatically uploading and downloading documents or searching for a specific file!
5759 | 
5760 | Some major enhancements to File Storage, thanks to feedback from our beta customers, are:
5761 | 
5762 | - File Picker: An out-of-the-box, UI-friendly feature that allows your customers to browse and select files and folders from their file storage platform, regardless of which one they use! (Note that this feature is still in beta, but if you would like to use it for your use case, please reach out to your EM or support@merge.dev.)
5763 | - Real-time files, folders, and drives with supported third-party webhooks.
5764 | - Support of files and folder permissions data using newly added Common Models: Users and Groups
5765 | 
5766 | Try it out now using our developer docs [here](https://docs.merge.dev/filestorage/overview/)! If you’re interested in discussing your specific use case and how Merge can support it, you can talk to someone [here](https://merge.dev/get-in-touch?utm_btn=dr-page-changelog).
5767 |

5984 | 
5985 | The [Merge Dashboard](https://app.merge.dev/) has gone through major enhancements to provide full visibility and control into each of your linked accounts.

5987 | Maintaining integrations is much more time consuming than the initial build, which is why we're excited about announcing our comprehensive suite of tools: Integrations Management.

6361 | ## Updates to Linked Account View in the Merge Dashboard
6362 | 
6363 | We are making major enhancements to Merge Dashboard’s [Linked Accounts section](https://app.merge.dev/linked-accounts/accounts) to make our integrations management capabilities even better to help your support teams easily identify and address end user errors. We are excited to rollout the following changes.
6364 | 
6365 | - We’ve added reference docs, API Tester, Help Center, and a Support button, so your support team can access a resource or contact support if there’s an issue with a specific Linked Account.
6366 | - We show a Linked Account’s metadata, data sync status and scope in a single view. This provides visibility in when data was last synced, relevant permission, and current sync status.
6367 | - Added advanced configuration settings, such as field mapping and sync frequencies speeds, highlighting these settings at each linked account level.

122 | # Merge is committed to supporting our growing European customer base
123 | 
124 | - 30% of Merge customers are based in Europe
125 | - Global offices in NYC, SF, and Berlin
126 | - Merge supports a wide range of European software integrations
127 | 
128 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67c9d99cc836a43206bebf1a_berlin%20v2%20with%20pill%20shapes-min.png)
129 | 
130 | [Data localization and transfer](https://www.merge.dev/eu#data-localization) [Data minimization](https://www.merge.dev/eu#data-minimization) [Data access and erasure](https://www.merge.dev/eu#data-access) [Accountability and compliance](https://www.merge.dev/eu#accountability) [Additional resources](https://www.merge.dev/eu#additional-resources)
131 | 
132 | #### Data localization and transfer
133 | 
134 | Merge puts in place a DPA ( [data processing agreement](https://www.merge.dev/legal/data-processing-agreement)) with all customers, whereby Merge commits to processing data transfers in accordance with GDPR’s Standard Contractual Clauses. In addition, Merge offers customers control over where their data is stored.
135 | 
136 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67b9e5a942959918e094ba51_Frame%202087327457.png)
137 | 
138 | ##### EU-tenants
139 | 
140 | If the customer selects our EU multi-tenant environment, data will only be stored in the EU in Stockholm
141 | 
142 | [Learn more\\
143 | \\
144 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/5389408-merge-data-encryption-and-storing-standards)
145 | 
146 | ##### Single-tenants
147 | 
148 | Receive your own servers and databases that are fully separated from other Merge customers
149 | 
150 | #### Data minimization
151 | 
152 | Meaningfully control and limit what data is shared
153 | 
154 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67b9e9be73d2b1b6e8179d21_gdpr-2.svg)
155 | 
156 | ##### Scopes
157 | 
158 | Set precise scopes to sync only what’s needed, respecting your customers’ data privacy
159 | 
160 | [Learn more\\
161 | \\
162 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/5950052-what-are-common-model-scopes)
163 | 
164 | ##### Selective sync
165 | 
166 | Configure data synced to Merge based on third-party fields and parameters
167 | 
168 | [Learn more\\
169 | \\
170 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/9113654-selective-sync)
171 | 
172 | ##### Redact unmapped data
173 | 
174 | Redact data from third-party unmapped fields to hide sensitive data from logs and remote data
175 | 
176 | [Learn more\\
177 | \\
178 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/8358419-what-is-redact-unmapped-data)
179 | 
180 | #### Data access and erasure
181 | 
182 | Seamlessly delete any data at any time
183 | 
184 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67b9eb2e84b37ae06005b6d8_gdpr-3.svg)
185 | 
186 | ##### Data deletion via ignore endpoint
187 | 
188 | Exclude accessing specific individuals' personal data, while continuing to pull others
189 | 
190 | [Learn more\\
191 | \\
192 | Arrow Right](https://docs.merge.dev/hris/employees/#employees_ignore_create)
193 | 
194 | ##### Linked Account deletion
195 | 
196 | When a Linked Account is deleted, all data associated with that account is also deleted from Merge
197 | 
198 | [Learn more\\
199 | \\
200 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/5388451-deleting-a-linked-account)
201 | 
202 | #### Accountability and compliance
203 | 
204 | Automatically keep detailed records of data processing activities and easily restrict access to Merge
205 | 
206 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67b9fa97aea0512d75d3f983_gdpr-4svg.svg)
207 | 
208 | ##### Audit trail
209 | 
210 | Full transparency and accountability for all user actions in the Merge Dashboard
211 | 
212 | [Learn more\\
213 | \\
214 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/8813877-merge-audit-trail-enhancing-security-compliance)
215 | 
216 | ##### SSO with SAML
217 | 
218 | Compatible with Single Sign-On (SSO) with Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML), control access to the Merge dashboard and enforce organizational policies
219 | 
220 | ##### Role-based access control
221 | 
222 | Restrict what type of access Merge users have based on their assigned role
223 | 
224 | #### Additional resources
225 | 
226 | [Merge Trust Center\\
227 | \\
228 | Arrow Right](https://trust.merge.dev/)
229 | 
230 | [Privacy Policy\\
231 | \\
232 | Arrow Right](https://merge-landing-page.webflow.io/legal/privacy-policy)
233 | 
234 | [Data Processing Agreement\\
235 | \\
236 | Arrow Right](https://merge-landing-page.webflow.io/legal/data-processing-agreement)

180 | Integrations platform
181 | 
182 | ## Complete API functionality for hundreds of integrations
183 | 
184 | One integration is never enough.
185 | 
186 | Merge integrates HRIS, ATS, accounting, ticketing, CRM, and file storage products — big or small.
187 | 
188 | [Explore integrations](https://www.merge.dev/integrations?category=All+Integrations)
189 | 
190 | Normalized data
191 | 
192 | # Say goodbye to data transformations
193 | 
194 | Merge designs common data models for each category of software APIs. Plug into well-structured data without being an expert in every third-party API.
195 | 
196 | [Explore integrations\\
197 | \\
198 | Arrow Right](https://docs.merge.dev/hris/overview/)
199 | 
200 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d80619e7acd2f5977171dd_Normalize%20data%20code%20snippet.avif)
201 | 
202 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d80feebf3e871a2cb00d84_writes-im.avif)
203 | 
204 | Unified writes
205 | 
206 | # Read anything, write anything
207 | 
208 | POST any request you want. Anticipate required fields for any third-party API, completely programmatically.
209 | 
210 | For complex schemas, use object relationships and nesting to craft a single request that works across all API providers.
211 | 
212 | [View Docs\\
213 | \\
214 | Arrow Right](https://docs.merge.dev/guides/merge-writes/)
215 | 
216 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d8686b7368d1b59e8e6552_Double%20emboss%20bg%20(1).avif)
217 | 
218 | Customized data filtering
219 | 
220 | # Toggle, sync, and filter your customer data
221 | 
222 | #### Scopes
223 | 
224 | Define model and field-level scopes to ensure your users grant access only to the data required for your product's use case
225 | 
226 | [View Docs\\
227 | \\
228 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/5950052-what-are-common-model-scopes)
229 | 
230 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d82b524becb360860cd6f3_scopes.avif)
231 | 
232 | #### Selective Sync
233 | 
234 | Empower your customers to further refine data access with Selective Sync.
235 | 
236 | Configure which models are pulled based on their attributes — such as candidates who work Remotely or Employees who live in San Francisco.
237 | 
238 | [View Docs\\
239 | \\
240 | Arrow Right](https://help.merge.dev/en/articles/9113654-selective-sync)
241 | 
242 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d82edce3009d4b55ccfb80_selective%20sync.avif)
243 | 
244 | #### Normalized queries
245 | 
246 | Use normalized query parameters to filter the data you want to access
247 | 
248 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d82f614b8980388b092b20_normalized%20queries.avif)
249 | 
250 | Supplemental data
251 | 
252 | ## Anything possible by building directly is possible through Merge
253 | 
254 | For data that doesn’t fit the Common Model, make API requests directly to third parties or access original API responses prior to normalization. Capture any other non-standard data you want to structure with Custom Fields.
255 | 
256 | [View docs](https://docs.merge.dev/supplemental-data/)
257 | 
258 | Case study
259 | 
260 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67be2856ff1b02ae719a15dc_New%20Drata%20logo%20-%20black%20(1)%201%20(1).webp)
261 | 
262 | #### How Drata increases customer value and spends 80% less time managing integrations
263 | 
264 | [View case study\\
265 | \\
266 | Arrow Right](https://www.merge.dev/case-studies/how-drata-increases-customer-value-and-spends-80-less-time-managing-integrations)
267 | 
268 | ​​Working with Merge’s Unified API and beautiful React component took less than a sprint to integrate, test, and release.
269 | 
270 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67c80be662bbaed1753045a3_Daniel%20Marashlian%20-%20Drata.webp)
271 | 
272 | Daniel Marashlian
273 | 
274 | Co-Founder & CTO, Drata
275 | 
276 | ## Make integrations your competitive advantage
277 | 
278 | Stay in touch to learn how Merge can unlock hundreds of integrations in days, not years
279 | 
280 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67a0696c88fcb6b1a1d8ad6f_CTA%20Background%20Logo.svg)
281 | 
282 | Qualified
283 | 
284 | ## Looking to add integrations to your product?
285 | 
286 | Simply and securely add 100s of customer-facing integrations with one API
287 |

180 | ## What is a Common Model?

192 | # Create structured custom fields and attributes. Write back custom data.

194 | #### Field Mapping
195 | 
196 | You or your user can customize every data model through a no-code UI. Access fields via API.

182 | Integration dashboard
183 | 
184 | ## All of your integrations and accounts at a glance
185 | 
186 | Reduce time spent on integration maintenance by 80%. Give your support team complete visibility with automated alerts and real-time monitoring — no engineering intervention required.
187 | 
188 | Automated issue detection
189 | 
190 | ## Turn early warnings into instant solutions
191 | 
192 | Merge’s automated monitoring system catches common integration hiccups — from expired API keys to permission gaps — so your support team can take action before disruptions occur
193 | 
194 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d7e539abc01bc60bdab41b_automated%20issue%20detection%20image.avif)

180 | How it works
181 | 
182 | ## Infinitely scale your integrations
183 | 
184 | Merge exposes a Unified API with common data models for each category of integrations. Authenticate integrations on behalf of your customers with Merge Link and then access the data synced by the Unified API from a Merge SDK.
185 | 
186 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93fc2b70a27d806b26d59_how-right-part.svg)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93fc2136e72aa3cdc9e32_Your%20product%20(robin%2C%20no%20sidebar).svg)
187 | 
188 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93fc35b0515986b4c6683_card.svg)
189 | 
190 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d9368a0168bbc2eae358c4_scalability.avif)
191 | 
192 | Scalable and reliable
193 | 
194 | ## Never worry about reliability
195 | 
196 | Merge is built on a fault-tolerant AWS infrastructure and boasts 99.999% uptime
197 | 
198 | Data residency
199 | 
200 | ## Choose where your data lives
201 | 
202 | Merge hosts your data in a geography of your choice to meet your data residency requirements
203 | 
204 | ‍
205 | 
206 | Select from:
207 | 
208 | - Multi-tenant US
209 | - Multi-tenant EU
210 | - Multi-tenant APAC
211 | - Single-tenant in a region of your choice
212 | 
213 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d9390eaa94974331137ae2_Link%20localization%20globe.avif)
214 | 
215 | ## Security and compliance are our foundation
216 | 
217 | Designed from the ground up to safeguard your customer data, Merge adheres to the industry’s highest standards of security and privacy and is certified in SOC 2 Type II, ISO 27001, HIPAA, and GDPR
218 | 
219 | [Security at Merge](https://www.merge.dev/security)
220 | 
221 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93b94918dee04956184d8_AiCPA%20American%20Institute%20of%20Certified%20Public%20Accountants%201.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93b944fb19f657efdfa7a_ISOlogo%201.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93b9457c01667189d0db2_hippa.png)![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d93b9420a7dc5bc5b8bdbb_gdpr-security.png)
222 | 
223 | Case study
224 | 
225 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67be2856ff1b02ae719a15dc_New%20Drata%20logo%20-%20black%20(1)%201%20(1).webp)
226 | 
227 | #### How Drata increases customer value and spends 80% less time managing integrations
228 | 
229 | [View case study\\
230 | \\
231 | Arrow Right](https://www.merge.dev/case-studies/how-drata-increases-customer-value-and-spends-80-less-time-managing-integrations)
232 | 
233 | ​​Working with Merge’s Unified API and beautiful React component took less than a sprint to integrate, test, and release.
234 | 
235 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/62796ab9647626cbab663f42/67c80be662bbaed1753045a3_Daniel%20Marashlian%20-%20Drata.webp)
236 | 
237 | Daniel Marashlian
238 | 
239 | Co-Founder & CTO, Drata
240 | 
241 | ## Make integrations your competitive advantage
242 | 
243 | Stay in touch to learn how Merge can unlock hundreds of integrations in days, not years
244 | 
245 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67a0696c88fcb6b1a1d8ad6f_CTA%20Background%20Logo.svg)
246 | 
247 | Qualified
248 | 
249 | ## Looking to add integrations to your product?
250 | 
251 | Simply and securely add 100s of customer-facing integrations with one API
252 | 
253 | Get a demoChat with an expertDownload product integrations eBook
254 |

180 | Syncing
181 | 
182 | #### Keep all your data in sync
183 | 
184 | Ensure the freshest data with multiple sync options from third-party APIs to Merge to your backend, including webhooks, periodic polling, and forced resyncs. Plus, you can always POST or PATCH data instantly.
185 | 
186 | [View Docs\\
187 | \\
188 | Arrow Right](https://docs.merge.dev/basics/syncing-data/)
189 | 
190 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67d92eac61dcf1097d5a6c4f_Syncing.avif)
191 | 
192 | Webhooks
193 | 
194 | #### Get notified when the latest data drops
195 | 
196 | Merge generates webhooks whenever updated data is available so you can keep your database up to date with minimal polling. You can also access webhooks emitted directly from third-party API providers.
197 | 
198 | Even better, Merge is able to set up these webhooks right out of the box, where supported. No configuration from you or your end user required.
199 | 
200 | [View Docs\\
201 | \\
202 | Arrow Right](https://docs.merge.dev/basics/webhooks/overview/)
203 | 
204 | ![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/624b192df0b0151225c10026/67dabdba342b6b18463d9b7d_webhooks.svg)
205 | 
206 | Rate limiting
207 | 
208 | #### Don’t be limited as you scale
209 | 
210 | Merge features a smart rate limiting engine to dynamically handle differences in rate limits and pagination across integrations. You'll never be limited by what data you access.
211 |

Following submission of certain required information by a user, including, at the discretion of the user, the user’s email address (the “ **Input**”), the Tool will generate and display a set of preliminary relationships between the Partner Models and the Common Models (the “ **Output**”). The Tool is not part of the Service. Use of the Service is governed by the [Subscriber Agreement](https://merge.dev/legal/subscriber-agreement).
